I’m going to close this in favor of adding a dynamic framework target instead. As I cannot get the tests to run on CI without having an Xcode scheme. The recreate schemes action in fastlane (and the library it depends on) doesn’t support creating an Xcode scheme with tests.

That sounds odd. As far as I remember, the UICollectionView shouldn't ask for a new count before the batch update, it should only compare the latest value returned from `numberOfItemsInSection:`, usually from the previous reload. 

Did you look at which points in time it triggers the `numberOfItemsInSection:`-call when this error occurs?

Thanks for the input. I will try to write a test that captures this case, then we can use it even if we update the solution. @JohnSundell I missed that the delegate is called when the viewModel updates, that definitely requires changes. I have 100% reproducible scenario and validated that `numberOfItemsInSection:` is called before and after the batch update but I can try to post more concrete example later. 
Posting some links from people that had similar problem and fixed it with a different approach:
https://fangpenlin.com/posts/2016/04/29/uicollectionview-invalid-number-of-items-crash-issue/
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/37846653/nightmare-with-performbatchupdates-crash

@JohnSundell No we don’t want it to crash since it could, and should, just fail the test instead. Allowing the rest of the suite to run. Which will happen after this PR. The current behavior will be that the tests, if there’s for example CPU congestion, crashes and no other tests will be ran.

What happens is a edge case of `XCTestExpectation`’s API. For reference see http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27555499/xctestexpectation-how-to-avoid-calling-the-fulfill-method-after-the-wait-contex/27555500#27555500

@JohnSundell the cause of the crash is related to the fix I did last week (https://github.com/spotify/HubFramework/pull/141) where the bounds-checking was changed as the view model child count might not align with the collection view's item count at all times. 

However, it seems like the `numberOfItemsInSection:` will actually trigger a call to the data source if the collection view hasn't done any prior item counts, potentially causing the collection view to report having more items than there are layout attributes for (as the UICollectionViewLayout is computed manually in combination with the reloading, which hasn't occurred yet). 

So the crash would remain if `frameForBodyComponentAtIndex:` was called after the view model was updated but _before the first rendering pass_. 

Yay UIKit \o/

[15:09:30]: ▸ ❌  /Users/travis/build/spotify/HubFramework/sources/HUBViewControllerImplementation.m:1476:38: variable length array used [-Werror,-Wvla]

Don't we support variable-length arrays? It's been in the standard for a while 😛
@JohnSundell Just added the test. This is a really amazing framework! Glad I can offer some help. 👍

@goos: Yes and no. VLA's _can_ be dangerous. They (may) allocate space on the stack, so you need to be careful. For small value, it's very efficient, but if you inadvertently pass a large value in, it can have consequences.

In this particular case it's likely fine, but you could probably also get away with a fixed-length buffer and an assertion. Index path lengths usually aren't particularly long.
@dflems good point – but doesn't that apply for most things C? E.g. sending an unintentionally large size to malloc :smile:

@goos: True, true. In this case it definitely seems fine.

Also, please remove the project changes and add this to `WARNING_CFLAGS` in `spotify_os.xcconfig` (and push [upstream](https://github.com/spotify/ios-ci)).

@marmelroy We can add the linting later. Since it’ll require some infrastructure to be added 😄
Thanks @rastersize. Good catch.

Thanks for the feedback.

A universal framework is much easier to maintain and that's a huge plus. The main technical argument against a universal framework was that Carthage couldn't build it but that's no longer the case. 

See these for context:
https://github.com/Alamofire/Alamofire/pull/326
https://github.com/Alamofire/Alamofire/pull/1064

Any other argument we should consider in favour of a platform-specific framework? 

An additional difference with @JohnSundell's implementation is that I added an explicit HubComponentWithFocusState protocol whereas John merged focus state with highlighted state. 

I will update the PR with the changes requested by @rastersize and @cerihughes and will steal a couple of ideas from @JohnSundell's branch 😄

@cerihughes I’m in favor of the changes made in this PR. Unless we explicitly want to check that two objects are the same instance we should use `XCTAssertEqualObjects(obj1, obj2, desc, …)`.

Further I think we should, like you’re doing here, use `XCTAssertTrue()` with a description (or comment) when we actually want to check for instance equality. I’d also be fine with adding a function or macro like `HUBAssertEqualInstances(ins1, ins2, desc, …)` to make the code more self-explanatory.
@marmelroy Thank you for the links and update, much appreciated! From reading the Alamofire discussions I think we should probably go with multiple targets. Like you’ve done in this PR.

Sorry for the delay in fixing this - moving countries is quite time exhaustive. This PR should be ready for another review (cc @cerihughes, @rastersize ). 

Summary of changes:
- Syntax was improved as per @cerihughes request. 
- Change requested re unsigned enums was applied framework-wide. 
- Change requested re configuration overrides was due to duplication of the dynamic target on production. Overrides were removed from both iOS and tvOS targets.
- The test target was improved a little. 

Note:
testScrollingToBottomOfViewLoadsPaginatedContent was being flaky. I improved the log we get when it fails. We should monitor the issue.

@mhallendal @spotify/objc-dev

Nice find, there is definitely state that will screw up in the ways you described by throwing away only the `collectionView` and `viewModel`. 

`registeredCollectionViewCellReuseIdentifiersregisteredCollectionViewCellReuseIdentifiers` keeps track of registered classes and will contain classes registered with a deallocated `UICollectionView` and the `HUBViewRenderer` keeps track of the last view model so it will calculate a diff against a different view model than the `HUBViewController` knows about.

@rastersize Definitely agree about migration guide from 2.0 -> 3.0. I didn't add one for this step since I think/hope that we have been able to separate the various parts enough to obsolete the `HUBConfig` as well before we stabilise for 3.x.

How about we add a migration path to the future PR removing `HUBManager` where you'll be forced to migrate and let the change to the demo app be the example for those that want to migrate earlier?

@rastersize re. initial view model registry. You can already handle it through the normal content loading by just having a content operation provide the initial view model without any network traffic.

Longer term we want to reverse the content loading (ie. the view controller has a setter for the view model and it's being fed from the outside, rather than pulled from the view controller. And in fact the view controller doesn't know about the view model loaders existens). That way the view model loader doesn't need to be involved in setting an initial view model.

Small issue: adding a new method in the scroll handler protocol is technically a breaking change as it requires updating all classes that conform to the protocol.

I did consider making it an optional method but the fact that the scroll handler is of an "id" type and doesn't inherit from NSObject means I can't check if the the delegate responds to the optional selector.
If you could create a github issue that addresses the duplication of behaviour that this adds, we can go back to it later and work on that.

I don't think we need to inject the `UIApplication` any further up (or is it down?) the stack than the VC... I think it's OK for the "root" objects like `HUBConfigBuilder` and `HUBManager` to call `[UIApplication sharedApplication]` internally and inject that into everything else that needs it downstream. Maybe there's a more suitable "root" object in Hubs that we could use (but I think these 2 are about as "root" as it gets).

This is much like `client-ios` where root objects like service/feature implementations generally access static singletons and inject them into all objects from that point (or at least, that's how *I* think it should be working).

I don't think we should be exposing the application through the API as a `HUBApplication` either as that's confusing for users. Doing the above means we don't have to do this either
... in other words, I don't think there should be any changes to the `include` APIs for this change. It should be purely an implementation change.

... but if we *do* create a protocol for the VC (there are still other cases where it's easier if it's a concrete class), we'd want to expose this in the API as `UIViewController<HUBViewController> *`, not `id<HUBViewController>`.

I think we should get to a point where we're not experimenting so much with different VC implementations and then look at whether using a protocol in the API is feasible.

For now, let's keep it as it is.

Oh... is it because we don't have a mocking framework and so can't properly mock a `UIApplication`?
@cerihughes Yes, it’s because we don’t have a mocking framework.
@krris Can we just subclass `UIApplication` for testing purposes (in the same way we do for `HUBCollectionViewMock` for example)?
@rastersize @mhallendal Yes, that makes sense. I don't see why I didn't do it like that. Go ahead

@cerihughes Unfortunately we cannot. If we create `HUBApplicationMock` which is a subclass of `UIApplication`, we won't be able to instantiate it, because there can only be one `UIApplication` instance.

We *do* have the option of subclassing `NSObject` instead of `UIApplication` and just mirroring the API that we use on that subclass.

I'm all for writing code that's easy to test, but I think that needing changes to the public API just to be testable is a step too far. WDYT?

I had to do some more changes to make it test OK:
- Upgrade to using Xcode 9.3 on Travis-CI.
  - They don’t support Xcode 9.4 yet.
- Upgrade demo app and live utility to Swift 4.
- Add support for running tests on iOS 11.
  - One test has been disabled.
  - Some tests had to be modified to be able to find the navigation bar title.
  - Disable iOS’ automatic content insets adjustment as HubFramework does not work well with it.
This PR should also make `master` green again 😄
